awd_titl_txt: RUI:   Characterization of thiamine signal transduction pathway in Candida glabrata and other Ascomycetes
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to understand how closely related fungal species have changes in their genome specific to nutrient starvation, and how those subtle genomic differences allow for changes in each species' behavior. This work studies the thiamine signal transduction (THI) pathway in the yeast species Candida glabrata, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, and other related species, to determine if pathway function is predictable from genomic sequence. Thiamine (vitamin B1) is required by all living organisms to metabolize sugars, is synthesized de novo in most microorganisms, and it is a dietary requirement in all animals. In this project, researchers at Villanova University, including undergraduate and Master's students, will characterize in detail how vitamin B1 is synthesized in various yeast species, with a focus on two species - Saccharomyces cerevisiae (or budding yeast) and Candida glabrata. Using this detailed characterization, the investigators will then use this information to develop predictions as to how uncharacterized yeast species will behave in response to thiamine starvation. This project will educate and motivate the next generation of scientists by training them in modern molecular biological techniques. Undergraduates working on this project will, on average, spend over two and a half years working on their research, will take responsibility for their projects and present their data at professional meetings and in scientific journals, giving them a rigorous foundation to continue STEM studies after graduation. In the long-term, because thiamine is essential for growth, gaining a deep understanding of how thiamine is made and acquired will be critical for the development of interventions to prevent fungal growth.

C. glabrata requires thiamine to be supplied for growth, unlike many yeast species that can synthesize it de novo. During thiamine starvation, S. cerevisiae upregulates ~10 genes (called THI genes) using the transcriptional regulators Thi2, Thi3, and Pdc2. C. glabrata lacks 1) one half of the thiamine biosynthetic pathway, 2) the ancestral phosphatase required for thiamine recycling, and 3) the conserved transcription factor Thi2. Because these species have differences in how they acquire and synthesize thiamine, a detailed understanding of the THI pathway in both species is required to use genomic sequence to predict behaviors of uncharacterized, sequenced yeast species, and to understand the evolution of the THI pathway more generally. This project will identify DNA elements essential for the thiamine starvation response using promoter truncation and promoter fusion experiments. After identification of TREs (or thiamine responsive elements), the researchers will determine whether these TREs are sufficient for thiamine starvation regulation; will use a SEL-seq approach to identify the sequence determinants of the TREs; use ChIP-seq to confirm Pdc2 binding to the TREs; and determine the commonalities of regulation with the two species S. cerevisiae and C. glabrata. After a detailed characterization of these two species, the researchers will reconstitute the C. glabrata pathway into S. cerevisiae (and the reverse - the S. cerevisiae THI pathway into C. glabrata). This reconstitution will allow investigators to validate that all components necessary for regulation of THI genes have been identified, and to test the predictive power of the results in other evolutionarily related species (focusing on the Nakaseomyces clade) where only DNA sequence is known. When this work is completed, researchers should be able to predict which yeast species 1) can synthesize thiamine, 2) are altered in their ability to recycle thiamine, and 3) may have come to other evolutionary solutions to surviving when thiamine is not present.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Thiamine, or vitamin B1, is critical to all life. The vitamin is vital for the metabolism of carbohydrates, and cells that that lack this vitamin are unable to live. Most microorganisms (and plants) synthesize thiamine for metabolism, and most animals acquire thiamine from their diet. In this work, we examined the thiamine signal transduction pathway in the mammalian commensal fungus, Candida glabrata. C. glabrata, unlike most yeast species, is unable to synthesize thiamine, but it still contains elements of the synthesis pathway and retains a simplified regulatory pathway that allows cells to respond to starvation of environmental thiamine. Because of the partial retention of the pathway, we examined how this pathway transduces starvation from outside the cell to the transcriptional upregulation of genes that allow it to survive thiamine starvation. Because C. glabrata is the second most common cause of yeast infections, thrush, and candidiasis, understanding how this species acquires thiamine from its environment has implications for eventually developing novel antifungal treatments.

This work specifically examined the transcription of thiamine biosynthetic and transporter genes. While the pathway is partially lost, explaining why cells require exogenous thiamine, these genes are upregulated during thiamine starvation when grown in synthetic medium. Using promoter deletion and site-directed mutagenesis analysis, we were able to define an 11 bp sequence in the CgPMU3 promoter, and a 13 bp sequence in all other thiamine regulated promoters that served as critical elements required for transcriptional upregulation of promoters in response to thiamine starvation. We determined that these two elements behave differently from one another, and that the 11 bp element is a newly evolved element that confers much of the behaviors of the ancestral 13 bp element that is conserved in other yeast species. We generated a model to explain why ancestral promoters behave differently from this CgPMU3 promoter. The Pmu3 protein is critical for cells to acquire thiamine, and because it is recently evolved, understanding how a new gene and its promoter behave generates interesting evolutionary questions in addition to providing a key target for the development of antifungal compounds.

Our work with the thiamine regulated promoters then provided an entr?e into understanding how the transcription factor Pdc2 regulates these different promoters. We were able to narrow down specific regions of promoters, understand how Pdc2 binds to those promoters, and clarify the phenotypes of strains that have lost PDC2. This work has built to a final story that indicates precisely where Pdc2 is binding and how the CgPMU3 promoter is different from ancestral thiamine regulated promoters. We will publish this work in 2024.

Finally, our work has uncovered the role of gene repression in C. glabrata. Work of an undergraduate asked whether the general transcriptional repressor Tup1 was important for thiamine starvation in C. glabrata. Her work indicated that repression is not critical for thiamine regulation but has uncovered novel insights into the Tup1 family of proteins. C. glabrata, unlike the model yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, contains two copies of Tup1, and our work determined that the uncharacterized Tup11 protein is more important for transcriptional repression in C. glabrata, and potentially regulates genes that are important for survival in the mammalian immune system.

This work has had significant broader impacts on many individuals and has extended areas of research for people interested in treating C. glabrata infections. At the level of students, fourteen undergraduates and four master?s students were directly supported by this funding, either through salary or reagents. Five of those undergraduates have gone on to Ph.D. programs, four have gone on to advanced degree programs in a health profession, and two master?s students have gone to Ph.D. programs. Only two of the eighteen students are not currently engaged in a STEM discipline. Additionally, a laboratory manager and the primary investigator were supported. As this funding was during the height of COVID, this funding allowed individuals to be paid and productive. The completed work also has opened up new avenues of research. Individuals interested in developing antifungal drugs towards C. glabrata have a detailed understanding of a key gene required for C. glabrata to acquire thiamine from mammalian hosts, and investigators can follow up on the observation that Tup11 is important for the repression of pathogenicity related genes. Finally, this grant supported the ability for students at Villanova University to be exposed to cutting-edge science.
